channel.description: Recent content in Plot on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to the course on Plot. It’s by far the longest one out of all my courses on creative writing.

item.title: What is plot?
item.description: For most people, the definition of plot is simply “the things that happen”. And, honestly, you don’t need much more than that.

item.title: Promise, Progress, Payoff
item.description: This is the simplest way of thinking about plot that I found practical and useful. The “three P’s”: Promise, Progress, Payoff.

item.title: Promises
item.description: As mentioned in the previous chapter, every storyline starts with a promise. You promise the reader what it’s going to be like.

item.title: Progress
item.description: Previous chapter taught you how to make great promises at the start of your story. Now you need to progress those promises.

item.title: Payoff
item.description: If you created good Promises and Progress, the Payoff should flow naturally. If you get stuck thinking of a “cool ending” for the story, as if you could just create any ending you want, it reveals you haven’t made clear promises and progress.

item.title: Show versus Tell
item.description: Okay, so you have a plot. You have some events and information to get across. You need to communicate these to the reader, write it down in some way.

item.title: Conflict
item.description: Previous chapter gave you an idea of how to get scenes or chapters out of your plot. How to know which parts you should show, and which you should just tell with a literal sentence.

item.title: Plot Archetypes I
item.description: As mentioned before, most plots have already been done. In fact, if you look at stories from a distance, you’ll find that 99% of stories pull from the same collection of plot archetypes.

item.title: Plot Archetypes II
item.description: The archetypes below are from the popular Save the Cat books. (Read the full book if you want more details, examples, and more.

item.title: Plot Archetypes III
item.description: Credit for this overview of plot archetypes goes to SB Morrison. I debated about including this, because his own article is well-written and it’s his work.

item.title: Plot Archetypes IV
item.description: As promised, here’s my longest list of plot archetypes. Any idea you have can be categorized as one or multiple of these, although it might take a bit more searching.

item.title: Improv Plotting
item.description: This technique is one of the first rules of improvisational theatre. It’s a simple way to always keep a story going, to always move the plot forward.

item.title: Opening & Closing Scenes
item.description: When I wrote my first stories, I had a funny issue with every chapter. I had no intuition for when to start or end a chapter.

item.title: Theme-Driven
item.description: So far, we’ve focused on plot in a very practical way. The specific events, conflicts, and consequences. This chapter challenges you to write a plot using a different approach: one driven by theme, first and foremost.

item.title: Plot Points & Turns
item.description: This is a plotting tool I invented myself, after researching narrative structures for a long time. (You can see the results of all that in my Storytelling course.

item.title: Character-Driven
item.description: A few chapters ago, we had the theme-driven plot. This chapter does something similar, but now your plot is driven by character.

item.title: Play with Timing
item.description: We’ve discussed what should happen in your plot and why. This chapter talks about when events should happen. As a writer, you have the unique ability to move your plot around in time.

item.title: The Focus Shift
item.description: This is another plotting tool I invented, after writing several stories that were just not good enough and that received feedback from professional editors.

item.title: Death in Every Scene
item.description: I don’t know the source of this idea, as I learned it long ago. When I did, though, it immediately made my writing much better.

item.title: Rule of Three
item.description: Previous chapter already set up this chapter. I mentioned how stories typically threaten death once or twice before actually going through with it.

item.title: Folktales
item.description: Folktales are a favorite of mine. First of all, I just love those kinds of stories. Secondly, their general structure and themes strike close to the core of storytelling, which allows them to hook any reader.

item.title: Snapshots Method
item.description: Often, when a writer has a story idea, they have these “cool moments” in their head. They picture a great battle, a surprising betrayal, a wondrous magical event.

item.title: The Agenda Method
item.description: This is an amalgamation of several outlining methods that basically say the same thing. This one is for those of us who like planning and outlining, surely not for the improvisers!

item.title: Serialized versus Episodic
item.description: This chapter is about telling a story in multiple parts. (Such as a book series or multiple episodes for a TV show.

item.title: Story Ships
item.description: This is the final “plotting tool” or “writing challenge” I will give you. After this chapter will be more specific chapters about common mistakes or questions about plotting.

item.title: First Chapters
item.description: This article contains some advice or common mistakes that writers make with their first chapter (or first scene). Most authors, including me, will tell you that the first chapter is absolutely the most important one in your novel.

item.title: Action I
item.description: This article talks about writing simple action in general. How to write the things that happen, both big and small, in your book.

item.title: Action II
item.description: Last chapter talked about writing simple action sentences. Knowing this, how do we string together a long list of actions for a full sequence?

item.title: Description
item.description: Description is an odd thing in storytelling. It obviously only applies to books: a visual medium does the describing by simply placing the object or setting in the frame.

item.title: Emotional versus Melodramatic
item.description: We’ve talked about how to write action and how to write description. When it came to action, the action needed to have an emotional foundation, otherwise the reader didn’t care.

item.title: Compelling versus Complicated
item.description: This is probably the hardest balance to strike. If your story is too simple, it feels boring and meaningless.

item.title: Spoilers versus Foreshadowing
item.description: Like most, I despise spoilers. Especially in more popular genres, the main draw of a story comes from mystery.

item.title: How to actually write it
item.description: Inventing a great plot is obviously not the same as actually writing it. With words, on the page, to actually put it in book form.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: This has probably been my longest course to date. It’s easily the longest of all the writing courses. Because, in the end, plot is the actual meat of the book.

item.title: Writing for target audiences
item.description: This is the final chapter of the course. (The next one is a short conclusion just to wrap things up nicely.
